# The [participle]{.subs} as a verb-like governor

## Introduction

The verb is the basic, and strongest, governor of a [faa3il]{.subs} or [maful]{.subs}.
[#mushtaqq]{.subs} nouns, because they are derived from the verb, can also govern in a verb-like manner.
In this chapter
we will discuss the rules of how such nouns may act as verb-like governors.

## The [ism_fail]{.subs} as a verb-like governor

The [ism_fail]{.subs} is the closest of the [mushtaqq]{.subs} nouns to the verb,
and thus the strongest of the [mushtaqq]{.subs} nouns in its capacity to act as a verb-like governor.

Consider the following sentence:

(@3amal_mush_zaydun_yaqoomu) [زَيْدٌ يَقُومُ]{.ar}  
    [Zayd -- he stands]{.trans}

As we know from chapter\ (ref),
this is a compound sentence.
[زَيْدٌ]{.ar} is the [mubtada]{.subs} of an outer sentence.
The [xabar]{.subs} of the outer sentence is the inner sentence
[يَقُومُ]{.ar}.

Instead of using the [mudarie]{.subs} verb
[يَقُومُ]{.ar},
we can use its [ism_fail]{.subs}
[قَائِم]{.ar}, thus:

(@3amal_mush_zaydun_qaaimun) [زَيْدٌ قَائِمٌ]{.ar}  
    [Zayd is standing]{.trans}

As you can see,
we have translated the [mudarie]{.subs} verb
[يَقُومُ]{.ar} as [stands]{.trans}
and the [ism_fail]{.subs}
[قَائِم]{.ar} as [standing]{.trans}.
We will discuss the difference in meaning between the [mudarie]{.subs} verb and the [ism_fail]{.subs} in more detail in chapter\ (ref), [ia]{.subs}.
For now, we will focus on the grammar of the two sentences.

There is one notable similarity between the grammar of examples (@3amal_mush_zaydun_yaqoomu) and (@3amal_mush_zaydun_qaaimun),
and one notable difference:

##### The similarity {.unnumbered}

The
[mudarie]{.subs} verb
[يَقُومُ]{.ar},
and the [ism_fail]{.subs}
[قَائِمٌ]{.ar}
both govern
a [mustatir]{.subs} [faa3il]{.subs} pronoun,
implicated as [[هُوَ]{.ar}].

##### The difference {.unnumbered}

The [mudarie]{.subs} verb
[يَقُومُ]{.ar}
and its [mustatir]{.subs} [faa3il]{.subs} pronoun 
[[هُوَ]{.ar}]
are complementary [3umdah]{.subs} elements that
constitute a complete sentence.
The 
[mustatir]{.subs} [faa3il]{.subs} pronoun 
[[هُوَ]{.ar}]
is the [muxbar3]{.subs}
and
the [mudarie]{.subs} verb
[يَقُومُ]{.ar}
is the [muxbar]{.subs}.
The sentence formed by
the [mudarie]{.subs} verb
[يَقُومُ]{.ar}
and its [mustatir]{.subs} [faa3il]{.subs} pronoun 
[[هُوَ]{.ar}]
is in place of a [ustate]{.subs} noun as the [xabar]{.subs} of the [mubtada]{.subs}
([زَيْدٌ]{.ar})
of the outer sentence.

On the other hand,
and the [ism_fail]{.subs}
[قَائِمٌ]{.ar}
and its
[mustatir]{.subs} [faa3il]{.subs} pronoun 
[[هُوَ]{.ar}]
are _not_ complementary [3umdah]{.subs} elements.
Rather,
[قَائِمٌ]{.ar} (as the [muxbar]{.subs})
and
[زَيْدٌ]{.ar}
(as the [muxbar3]{.subs})
are complementary [3umdah]{.subs} elements.
This is a simple sentence,
not a compound sentence.
The [mustatir]{.subs} [faa3il]{.subs} pronoun
[[هُوَ]{.ar}] is not the [3umdah]{.subs} element of any sentence.
But,
despite being
[fadlah]{.subs} from the perspective of sentence completion,
the [mustatir]{.subs} [faa3il]{.subs} pronoun
is an essential governee of the [ism_fail]{.subs}.

Let's take a look at another example:

(@) [رَأَيْتُ رَجُلًا قَائِمًا]{.ar}  
    [I saw a standing man.]{.trans}

The [3umdah]{.subs} elements of this sentence are 
[رَأَيْتُ]{.ar}: the verb [رَأَى]{.ar} and its [faa3il]{.subs} pronoun [تُ]{.ar}.
The entire phrase
[رَجُلًا قَائِمًا]{.ar} has only [fadlah]{.subs} elements.
[قَائِمًا]{.ar} is a [na3t]{.subs} of [رَجُلًا]{.ar}, governed by the verb [رَأَى]{.ar}.
The [ism_fail]{.subs}
[قَائِمًا]{.ar} has a [mustatir]{.subs} [faa3il]{.subs} pronoun
[[هُوَ]{.ar}] that refers back to [رَجُلًا]{.ar}.
But because 
[قَائِمًا]{.ar} is a ([fadlah]{.subs}) element of an existing sentence
(whose [3umdah]{.subs} elements are [رَأَيْتُ]{.ar}),
therefore it cannot be the [3umdah]{.subs} [muxbar]{.subs} of a new sentence with its [mustatir]{.subs} [faa3il]{.subs} pronoun 
[[هُوَ]{.ar}].

So, as you can see, whenever the [ism_fail]{.subs} has a [mustatir]{.subs} [faa3il]{.subs} pronoun,
that [faa3il]{.subs} pronoun is not the [muxbar3]{.subs} of any sentence.
This is because the [ism_fail]{.subs}, as a single element, is already a member of an existing sentence.

In contrast, a verb always forms a sentence (as the [muxbar]{.subs}) with its [faa3il]{.subs} (as the [muxbar3]{.subs}).
If we replace the [ism_fail]{.subs} [قَائِمًا]{.ar} with the verb [يَقُومُ]{.ar} thus:

(@) [رَأَيْتُ رَجُلًا **يَقُومُ**]{.ar}  

then [يَقُومُ]{.ar} is a complete sentence with the verb and its [mustatir]{.subs} [faa3il]{.subs} pronoun as [3umdah]{.subs} elements.
This complete sentence is the [na3t]{.subs} of [رَجُلًا]{.ar}.

## The [ism_fail]{.subs} as the governor of a [mustatir]{.subs} [faa3il]{.subs} pronoun

Let us look into the
[mustatir]{.subs} [faa3il]{.subs} pronoun of the [ism_fail]{.subs} in more detail.
It makes sense for a verb to have a [faa3il]{.subs} but how can a noun have a [faa3il]{.subs}?
The reason is that the [ism_fail]{.subs},
because of its closeness to the verb,
can act like one.
When acting with verbal force,
it can govern a [faa3il]{.subs}.
It can also, as we will see soon, [ia]{.subs},
govern a [mafulb]{.subs}.

The [faa3il]{.subs} of the [ism_fail]{.subs} is,
by default,
a [mustatir]{.subs} pronoun.
And it refers back to a referent that occurs before it.
In example (@3amal_mush_zaydun_qaaimun) [زَيْدٌ قَائِمٌ]{.ar}
the [faa3il]{.subs} of the [ism_fail]{.subs}
[قَائِمٌ]{.ar}
is the [mustatir]{.subs} pronoun [[هُوَ]{.ar}].
And the referent of this [faa3il]{.subs} pronoun is the [mubtada]{.subs} [زَيْدٌ]{.ar}.

DIAGRAM

Let's see another example:

(@) [صَاحَ الرَّجُلُ الْقَائِمُ]{.ar}  
    [The standing man shouted.]{.trans}

then [الْقَائِمُ]{.ar} governs a [mustatir]{.subs} [faa3il]{.subs} pronoun [[هُوَ]{.ar}], that refers back to [الرَّجُلُ]{.ar}.

The fact that the [ism_fail]{.subs} has a [mustatir]{.subs} [faa3il]{.subs} pronoun
is,
in fact,
the reason why a [ism_fail]{.subs} in the [xabar]{.subs} will match the [mubtada]{.subs} in gender.^[[Non-agreement of Mubtada and Khabar](https://drvaniya.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/12/Q33-Non-agreement-of-Mubtada-and-Khabar.pdf)]

For example, if we say:

(@) [هِنْدٌ قَائِمَةٌ]{.ar}  
    [Hind is standing.]{.trans}

then the feminine marker [ة]{.ar} is added to the [ism_fail]{.subs} [قَائِم]{.ar} only because it has to match the feminine gender of the [mustatir]{.subs} [faa3il]{.subs} pronoun [[هِيَ]{.ar}] that occurs with, and is governed by, the [ism_fail]{.subs}.
(The [mustatir]{.subs} [faa3il]{.subs} pronoun [[هِيَ]{.ar}] refers back to [هِنْد]{.ar}.)

When the referent of the [mustatir]{.subs} [faa3il]{.subs} pronoun changes for number or gender,
then the [mustatir]{.subs} [faa3il]{.subs} pronoun will change to match it.
For example:

(@3amal_mush_zaydaan_qaaimaan) [الزَّيْدَانِ قَائِمَانِ]{.ar}
    [[[حاشية الصبان على شرح الأشمونى لألفية ابن مالك]{.ar} 1/291](https://shamela.ws/book/11539/288#p1)]{.citex}  
    [The two Zayds are standing.]{.trans}

(@3amal_mush_zaydoon_qaaimoon) [الزَّيْدُونَ قَائِمُونَ]{.ar}
    [[[حاشية الصبان على شرح الأشمونى لألفية ابن مالك]{.ar} 1/291](https://shamela.ws/book/11539/288#p1)]{.citex}  
    [The Zayds are standing.]{.trans}

In example (@3amal_mush_zaydaan_qaaimaan) above,
the [mustatir]{.subs} [faa3il]{.subs} pronoun of [قَائِمَانِ]{.ar} is implicated as [هُمَا]{.ar}.

And in example (@3amal_mush_zaydoon_qaaimoon) 
the [mustatir]{.subs} [faa3il]{.subs} pronoun of [قَائِمُونَ]{.ar} is implicated as [هُمْ]{.ar}.

As a point of technicality,
the alif in the dual suffix of [قَائِمَانِ]{.ar} and the [و]{.ar} in the plural suffix of [قَائِمُونَ]{.ar}, are not themselves the [faa3il]{.subs} pronouns.^[haazimi 30/5 <https://shamela.ws/book/36130/531>]
Rather, the [faa3il]{.subs} pronouns for the [ism_fail]{.subs}s above are [mustatir]{.subs}.

This is different than for verbs.
In the verbs
[يَقُومَانِ]{.ar} and [يَقُومُونَ]{.ar},
the alif in [انِ]{.ar} and the [و]{.ar} in [ونَ]{.ar} are, themselves, considered the [faa3il]{.subs} pronouns.
And these pronouns are _[zaahir]{.subs}_, not [mustatir]{.subs}.

## The [ism_fail]{.subs} as the governor of a [mafulb]{.subs}

We have seen that the [ism_fail]{.subs},
when acting with verbal force, governs a [faa3il]{.subs}.
In a similar manner,
the [ism_fail]{.subs} for transitive verbs can, optionally, govern a [mafulb]{.subs}.
In order to introduce this behavior,
we use again, as our starting point, the [ustate]{.subs} [mudarie]{.subs} verb.
Consider the following example:

(@3amal_mush_zaydun_yadribu_3amran) [زَيْدٌ يَضْرِبُ عَمْرًا]{.ar}  
    [Zayd beats [#amr]{.trn2}]{.trans}

Example (@3amal_mush_zaydun_yadribu_3amran) above is parsed as follows:

* [زَيْدٌ]{.ar} is a [mubtada]{.subs}.
* [يَضْرِبُ]{.ar} is a [mudarie]{.subs} verb in the [ustate]{.subs}.
  It governs a [mustatir]{.subs} pronoun (implicated as [هُوَ]{.ar}) in the [ustate]{.subs} as its [faa3il]{.subs}. 
  The [mustatir]{.subs} [faa3il]{.subs} pronoun [هُوَ]{.ar} refers back to its referent: the [mubtada]{.subs} [زَيْدٌ]{.ar}.
* [عَمْرًا]{.ar} is a [mafulb]{.subs}, governed in the [astate]{.subs} by  the verb [يَضْرِبُ]{.ar}.
* [يَضْرِبُ عَمْرًا]{.ar} is an inner sentence which is in place of a [ustate]{.subs} noun as the [xabar]{.subs} of the [mubtada]{.subs} [زَيْدٌ]{.ar}.

Instead of using the verb [يَضْرِبُ]{.ar} in example (@3amal_mush_zaydun_yadribu_3amran) above
we may instead use its [ism_fail]{.subs}
[ضَارِب]{.ar}, thus:

(@3amal_mush_zaydun_daaribun_3amran) [زَيْدٌ ضَارِبٌ عَمْرًا]{.ar}  
    [Zayd is beating [#amr]{.trn2}]{.trans}

Example (@3amal_mush_zaydun_daaribun_3amran) is parsed as follows:

* [زَيْدٌ]{.ar} is a [mubtada]{.subs}.
* [ضَارِبٌ]{.ar} is the [xabar]{.subs} of the [mubtada]{.subs} [زَيْدٌ]{.ar}.
  It governs a [mustatir]{.subs} pronoun (implicated as [هُوَ]{.ar}) in the [ustate]{.subs} as its [faa3il]{.subs}. 
  The [mustatir]{.subs} [faa3il]{.subs} pronoun [هُوَ]{.ar} refers back to the [mubtada]{.subs} [زَيْدٌ]{.ar}.
* [عَمْرًا]{.ar} is a [mafulb]{.subs}, governed in the [astate]{.subs} by the [ism_fail]{.subs} [ضَارِبٌ]{.ar}.

As you can see,
the [ism_fail]{.subs}
[ضَارِبٌ]{.ar} can govern a [mafulb]{.subs} just like 
the verb [يَضْرِبُ]{.ar}.

However, while a transitive verb can govern a [mafulb]{.subs} unconditionally,
a [ism_fail]{.subs} can only govern a [mafulb]{.subs} if certain conditions are satisfied.
We will discuss these conditions in section\ (ref) below.

By the way,
we again highlight the difference in
the [faa3il]{.subs} of
the verb [يَضْرِبُ]{.ar}
vs 
the [faa3il]{.subs} of the [ism_fail]{.subs}
[ضَارِبٌ]{.ar}:
The verb [يَضْرِبُ]{.ar} and its [faa3il]{.subs} are complementary [3umdah]{.subs} pairs that constitute a complete sentence.
Whereas,
the [ism_fail]{.subs}
[ضَارِبٌ]{.ar} does not form a new sentence with its [faa3il]{.subs}.

### A [ism_fail]{.subs} defined by [ٱل]{.ar} as the governor of a [mafulb]{.subs}

Example (@3amal_mush_zaydun_daaribun_3amran) shows the government of a [mafulb]{.subs} by an [ism_fail]{.subs} that is not defined by [ٱل]{.ar}.
In a similar manner,
an [ism_fail]{.subs} that _is_ defined by [ٱل]{.ar}, can also govern a [mafulb]{.subs}.
For example:

(@hadha_aldaaribu_zaydan) [هَذَا الضَّارِبُ زَيْدًا]{.ar}
    [[[شرح ابن يعيش على المفصل]{.ar} 4/84](https://shamela.ws/book/13301/1448)]{.citex}  
    [This [person] is the beater of Zayd.]{.trans}

By the way, you my be wondering what is the difference between the sentence in example (@hadha_aldaaribu_zaydan) [هَذَا الضَّارِبُ زَيْدًا]{.ar} above,
and if we had used an [idaafah]{.subs} thus:

(@hadha_aldaaribu_zaydan) [هَذَا ضَارِبُ زَيْدٍ]{.ar}
    [This [person] is the beater of Zayd.]{.trans}

This is touched upon in section\ (ma3aani_ism_faa3il).

### Word order of the [mafulb]{.subs} and its governing [ism_fail]{.subs}

As with verbs, the [mafulb]{.subs} usually follows its governing [ism_fail]{.subs}
(as in the examples above).
But 
when an [ism_fail]{.subs} is not prefixed by [ال]{.ar}, then its
[mafulb]{.subs} is allowed to precede it.
So we can say:

(@) [هذا زيدا ضارب]{.ar}
    [[[شرح كتاب سيبويه للسيرافي]{.ar} 1/259](https://shamela.ws/book/17726/257)]{.citex}  
    [This [person] is beating Zayd.]{.trans}

While the [mafulb]{.subs} is permitted 
to precede its governing [ism_fail]{.subs}
(as above),
it is very common,
in such a case,
for a [laam_taqwiya]{.subs} to be used with an [indir_mafulb]{.subs} instead, thus:

(@) [هذا لِزيدٍ ضارب]{.ar}  
    [This [person], to Zayd, is beating.]{.trans}

(@) [لِلضَّيْفِ مُكْرِمٌ]{.ar}
    [Fischer 113]{.citex}  
    [to the guest, is honoring]{.trans}  
    (i.e. [honoring the guest]{.trans})  

The [laam_taqwiya]{.subs} is discussed in more detail in section\ (later chapter).^[See also Wright 2/69CD, Fischer §203 Note\ 2 p.\ 113 (who consider this [laam_taqwiya]{.subs} obligatory), and [النحو الوافي]{.ar} 2/475--476 (who doesn't consider it obligatory).]

Also,
the freedom for the governee of a [ism_fail]{.subs} to precede it is only given to the [ism_fail]{.subs} not prefixed by [ال]{.ar}.
When an [ism_fail]{.subs} is prefixed by [ال]{.ar}, then its
[mafulb]{.subs} is not allowed to precede it.^[[النحو الوافي]{.ar} 3/263](https://shamela.ws/book/10641/1489#p1)
So we cannot say:

(@) [x]{.subs} [هذا زيدا الضارب]{.ar}

We would have to say instead

(@) [v]{.subs} [هذا الضارب زيدا]{.ar}

### A dual or plural [ism_fail]{.subs} as the governor of a [mafulb]{.subs}

A dual or plural [ism_fail]{.subs} may govern a [mafulb]{.subs} just like the singular.
So we can say:

(@) [هذان ضاربان زيدًا]{.ar}
    [[[شرح ابن يعيش على المفصل]{.ar} 4/97](https://shamela.ws/book/13301/1461#p1)]{.citex}  
    [These two [persons] are beating Zayd.]{.trans}

(@) [هم ضاربون زيدًا]{.ar}
    [[[شرح ابن يعيش على المفصل]{.ar} 4/97](https://shamela.ws/book/13301/1461#p1)]{.citex}  
    [These [persons] are beating Zayd.]{.trans}

(@) [الهندات ضاربات عمرا]{.ar}
    [[[شرح كتاب سيبويه للسيرافي]{.ar} 1/439](https://shamela.ws/book/17726/437)]{.citex}  
    [The Hinds are beating [#eamr]{.trn2}.]{.trans}

[#ism_fail]{.subs}s defined by [ٱل]{.ar} are again also permitted:

(@) [هذان الضاربان زيدا]{.ar}
    [[[شرح كتاب سيبويه للسيرافي]{.ar} 2/40](https://shamela.ws/book/17726/538)]{.citex}  
    [These two are the beaters of Zayd.]{.trans}

(@) [هؤلاء الضاربون الرجل]{.ar}
    [[[شرح كتاب سيبويه للسيرافي]{.ar} 2/40](https://shamela.ws/book/17726/538)]{.citex}  
    [These are the beaters of the man.]{.trans}

(@) [وَٱلۡمُقِیمِینَ ٱلصَّلَوٰةَۚ وَٱلۡمُؤۡتُونَ ٱلزَّكَوٰةَ]{.quran}
    [[[سورة النساء]{.ar} 4:162](https://quran.com/4/162) cited by [[شرح كتاب سيبويه للسيرافي]{.ar} 2/40](https://shamela.ws/book/17726/538)]{.citex}  
    [And the establishers of prayer [especially] and the givers of zakāh]{.trans}

For plurals, the sound plurals are more worthy of being used as verb-like governors^[[[شرح ابن يعيش على المفصل]{.ar} 4/97](https://shamela.ws/book/13301/1461#p1)]
as in the examples above.
However, broken plurals are permitted as well.
So we can say:

(@) [الزيدون ضُرّابٌ عمرًا]{.ar}
    [[[شرح ابن يعيش على المفصل]{.ar} 4/97](https://shamela.ws/book/13301/1461#p1)]{.citex}  
    [The Zayds are beating [#eamr]{.trn2}.]{.trans}

(@) [الهِنْداتُ ضواربُ عَمْرًا]{.ar}
    [[[شرح ابن يعيش على المفصل]{.ar} 4/97](https://shamela.ws/book/13301/1461#p1)]{.citex}  
    [The Hinds are beating [#eamr]{.trn2}.]{.trans}

Flexible word order is again permitted for the dual and the plural as it was for the singular:

(@) [الزيدان عمرا ضاربان]{.ar}
    [[[شرح كتاب سيبويه للسيرافي]{.ar} 1/439](https://shamela.ws/book/17726/437)]{.citex}  
    [The two Zayds are beating [#eamr]{.trn2}.]{.trans}

(@) [الزيدون عَمْرًا ضُرّابٌ]{.ar}
    [[[شرح ابن يعيش على المفصل]{.ar} 4/97](https://shamela.ws/book/13301/1461#p1)]{.citex}  
    [The Zayds are beating [#eamr]{.trn2}.]{.trans}

(@) [الهندات عمرا ضاربات]{.ar}
    [[[شرح كتاب سيبويه للسيرافي]{.ar} 1/439](https://shamela.ws/book/17726/437)]{.citex}  
    [The Hinds are beating [#eamr]{.trn2}.]{.trans}

(@) [الهِنْداتُ عَمْرًا ضواربُ]{.ar}
    [[[شرح ابن يعيش على المفصل]{.ar} 4/97](https://shamela.ws/book/13301/1461#p1)]{.citex}  
    [The Hinds are beating [#eamr]{.trn2}.]{.trans}

## Conditions for the [ism_fail]{.subs} to govern a [mafulb]{.subs}

As we mentioned above,
there are conditions that must be satisfied in order for an [ism_fail]{.subs} to be able to govern a [mafulb]{.subs} in this manner.
The conditions are different for when the [ism_fail]{.subs} is defined by [ٱلْ]{.ar},
and when it is not defined by [ٱلْ]{.ar}.
We will discuss each of these cases separately below:

### When the [ism_fail]{.subs} is not defined by [ٱلْ]{.ar}

When the [ism_fail]{.subs} is not defined by [ٱلْ]{.ar},
then two conditions must be satisfied:

1. The verbal aspect of the [ism_fail]{.subs} must be imperfect.
   That is, it must indicate an ongoing (whether present or past) or future action.
   Examples:

   * present ongoing:

     (@) [هذا ضارب زيدا الآن]{.ar}
         [[شرح ابن عقيل على الألفية]{.ar} 3/106]{.citex}  
         [This [person] is beating Zayd now.]{.trans}

   * past ongoing:

     (@) [كان زيد ضاربا عمرا]{.ar}
         [[شرح ابن عقيل على الألفية]{.ar} 3/107]{.citex}  
         [Zayd was beating [#eamr]{.trn2}.]{.trans}

     (@) [وَكَلْبُهُمْ بَاسِطٌ ذِرَاعَيْهِ بَٱلْوَصِيدِ]{.quran}
         [[[سورة الكهف]{.ar} 18:18](https://quran.com/18/18) cited by [شرح ابن عقيل على الألفية]{.ar} 3/106]{.citex}  
         [while their dog stretched his forelegs at the entrance]{.trans}

   * future:

     (@) [هذا ضارب زيدا غَدًا]{.ar}
         [[شرح ابن عقيل على الألفية]{.ar} 3/106]{.citex}  
         [This [person] will beat Zayd tomorrow.]{.trans}

   If the verbal aspect indicated by the [ism_fail]{.subs} is perfect,
   then the [ism_fail]{.subs} may not govern a [mafulb]{.subs}.
   So, for example, we cannot say:

   (@) [x]{.subs} [هذا ضارب **زيدا** أمس]{.ar}
       [[شرح ابن عقيل على الألفية]{.ar} 3/106]{.citex}  
       [This [person] beat Zayd yesterday.]{.trans}

   If we desire to use the [ism_fail]{.subs}, then it will not have verbal force.
   And [زَيْد]{.ar} will have to be a [mudafil]{.subs} in a  [idaafah]{.subs}.
   Furthermore, this [idaafah]{.subs} will be _[ma3nawi]{.subs}_ (see chapter\ (ref)).

   (@3amal_mush_hadha_daaribu_zaydin_amsi) [هذا ضارب زيد أمس]{.ar}
       [[شرح ابن عقيل على الألفية]{.ar} 3/106]{.citex}  
       [This [person] was the beater of Zayd yesterday.]{.trans}

   An exception is made for
   for transitive verbs that take more than one [mafulb]{.subs},
   like [جعل]{.ar}, [أَعطى]{.ar}, etc.
   When the [ism_fail]{.subs} of such a verb is annexed to what would have been the first [mafulb]{.subs},
   then second [mafulb]{.subs} is permitted to be in the [astate]{.subs}, 
   even if the aspect is perfect.^[See also [[البحر المحيط لأبي حيان]{.ar}](https://tafsir.app/albahr-almuheet/35/1) for [سورة فاطر]{.ar} 35:1 and [[الدر المصون للسمين الحلبي]{.ar}](https://tafsir.app/aldur-almasoon/35/1) for [سورة فاطر]{.ar} 35:1]
   For example:
   
   (@) [هذا معطي زيد أمس درهما]{.ar}
       [[[شرح التسهيل لابن مالك]{.ar} 3/78](https://shamela.ws/book/13257/894#p1)]{.citex}  
       [This [person] was the giver of Zayd, yesterday, a dirham.]{.trans}  

   
   Even the first [mafulb]{.subs} may remain in the [astate]{.subs}, if separated from the [ism_fail]{.subs}.
   For example:
   
   (@) [هذا ظان أمس زيدا فاضلا]{.ar}
       [[[شرح التسهيل لابن مالك]{.ar} 3/78](https://shamela.ws/book/13257/894#p1)]{.citex}  
       [This [person] was the believer, yesterday, of Zayd as an eminent person.]{.trans}  

2. The second condition that should be satisfied is that the [ism_fail]{.subs} must have _[i3timaad]{.subs}_.
   This [i3timaad]{.subs} can be provided by the following means:

   * The [ism_fail]{.subs} occurs after a [adat_istifham]{.subs}.
     Example:

     (@) [أضارب زيد عمرا]{.ar}
         [[شرح ابن عقيل على الألفية]{.ar} 3/107]{.citex}  
         [Is Zayd beating [#eamr]{.trn2}?]{.trans}  

     (@) [هَلْ مُكْرِمٌ أَنْتَ زَيْدًا]{.ar}
         [Wright 2/65D]{.citex}  
         [Will you be treating Zayd with respect?]{.trans}  

   * The [ism_fail]{.subs} occurs after a [nidaa]{.subs} particle:
     Example:

     (@) [يا طالعا جبلا]{.ar}
         [[شرح ابن عقيل على الألفية]{.ar} 3/107]{.citex}  
         [O scaler [of] a mountain!]{.trans}  

   * The [ism_fail]{.subs} occurs in a negation:
     Example:

     (@) [ما ضارب زيد عمرا]{.ar}
         [[شرح ابن عقيل على الألفية]{.ar} 3/107]{.citex}  
         [Zayd is not beating [#eamr]{.trn2}.]{.trans}  

     (@) [مَا أَنْتَ بِتَابِعٍ قِبْلَتَهُمْ]{.quran}
         [[[سورة البقرة]{.ar} 2:145](https://quran.com/2/145) cited by Wright 2/65D]{.citex}  
         [Nor will you be a follower of their qiblah]{.trans}  

     (@) [مَا مُجِيرٌ أَحَدٌ عَدُوَّ أَحِبَّاءِهِ]{.ar}
         [Wright 2/65D]{.citex}  
         [No one gives protection to the enemy of his loved ones]{.trans}  

   * The [ism_fail]{.subs} occurs as a [na3t]{.subs}.
     Example:

     (@) [مررت برجل ضارب زيدا]{.ar}
         [[شرح ابن عقيل على الألفية]{.ar} 3/107]{.citex}  
         [I passed by a man beating Zayd.]{.trans}  

     (@) [مَرَرْتُ بِفَارِسٍ طَالِبٍ ثَأْرَ أَبِيهِ]{.ar}
         [Wright 2/65C]{.citex}  
         [I passed by a horseman (who was) seeking vengeance for (the murder of) his father]{.trans}  

     An implied [na3t]{.subs} is also considered permissible.
     Example:

     (@) [كَمْ مَالِئٍ عَيْنَيْهِ مِنْ شَيْءِ غَيْرِهِ]{.ar}
         [Wright 2/65C; [شرح ابن عقيل على الألفية]{.ar} 3/108]{.citex}  
         [How many a one fills his eyes with a thing of [someone] other than him]{.trans}    
         (i.e. [كَمْ شَخْصٍ مَالِئٍ]{.ar} [How many a person fills...]{.trans})

     (@) [كَنَاطِحٍ صَخْرَةً يَوْمًا لِيُوهِنَهَا]{.ar}
         [Wright 2/65C; [شرح ابن عقيل على الألفية]{.ar} 3/109]{.citex}  
         [Like the gorer of a rock, one day, to try to weaken it]{.trans}    
         (i.e. [كَوَعِلٍ نَاطِحٍ]{.ar} [like a goring mountain goat...]{.trans})

   * The [ism_fail]{.subs} occurs as a [hal]{.subs}.
     Example:

     (@) [جاء زيد راكبا فرسا]{.ar}
         [[شرح ابن عقيل على الألفية]{.ar} 3/107]{.citex}  
         [Zayd came riding a horse.]{.trans}  

   * The [ism_fail]{.subs} occurs as a [xabar]{.subs}.
     Example:

     (@) [زيد ضارب عمرا]{.ar}
         [[شرح ابن عقيل على الألفية]{.ar} 3/107]{.citex}  
         [Zayd is beating [#eamr]{.trn2}.]{.trans}  


     We will learn in later chapters, [ia]{.subs}, different forms of [xabar]{.subs}s.
     The following examples show these different forms, with references to the later chapters.

     (@) [كان زيد ضاربا عمرا]{.ar}
         [[شرح ابن عقيل على الألفية]{.ar} 3/107]{.citex}  
         [Zayd was beating [#eamr]{.trn2}.]{.trans}  
         (See chapter\ (kaana).)

     (@) [إن زيدا ضارب عمرا]{.ar}
         [[شرح ابن عقيل على الألفية]{.ar} 3/107]{.citex}  
         [Indeed Zayd is beating [#eamr]{.trn2}.]{.trans}  
         (See chapter\ (inna).)

     (@) [ظننت زيدا ضاربا عمرا]{.ar}
         [[شرح ابن عقيل على الألفية]{.ar} 3/107]{.citex}  
         [I thought Zayd [was] beating [#eamr]{.trn2}.]{.trans}  
         (See chapter\ (zanna).)

     (@) [أعلمت زيدا عمرا ضاربا بكرا]{.ar}
         [[شرح ابن عقيل على الألفية]{.ar} 3/107]{.citex}  
         [I let Zayd know [#eamr]{.trn2} is beating Bakr.]{.trans}  
         (See chapter\ (zanna).)

<!--
     (@) [زَيْدٌ ضَارِبٌ أَبُوهُ أَخًا لِي]{.ar}
         [Wright 2/65B]{.citex}  
         [Zayd, his father is beating a brother of mine.]{.trans}  
-->

### When the [ism_fail]{.subs} is defined by [ٱلْ]{.ar}

When the [ism_fail]{.subs} is defined by [ٱلْ]{.ar},
then it is permitted to govern a [mafulb]{.subs} for a perfect or imperfect aspect.
<!--
So we can say:

(@) [هذا الضارب زيدا الآن أو غدا أو أمس]{.ar}
    [[شرح ابن عقيل على الألفية]{.ar} 3/110]{.citex}  
    [This [person] is the beater of Zayd now/tomorrow/yesterday.]{.trans}
-->
Furthermore, no [i3timaad]{.subs} is required for it to be a governor,^[[[النحو الوافي]{.ar} 3/254](https://shamela.ws/book/10641/1480)]
(as was required for the [ism_fail]{.subs} without [ٱلْ]{.ar} in section\ (ref) above).

So we can say:

(@) [جاء الضارب زيداً أمسِ أو الآن أو غداً]{.ar}
    [[[شرح شذور الذهب للجوجري]{.ar} 2/683](https://shamela.ws/book/9134/666)]{.citex}  
    [The beater of Zayd came yesterday/today/tomorrow]{.trans}

## The [ism_fail]{.subs} as the governor of an [zaahir]{.subs} [faa3il]{.subs} pronoun

The [mustatir]{.subs} [faa3il]{.subs} pronoun becomes [zaahir]{.subs} in some circumstances.
In this section,
we will discuss one such circumstance.
Consider the sentence:

(@) [الفارس الحصانُ مُتْعِبُه]{.ar}
    [[النحو الوافي]{.ar} 1/463]{.citex}  

This grammar is parsed as follows:

* [الْفَارِسُ]{.ar} is the [mubtada]{.subs} of the outer sentence.
* [الْحِصَانُ]{.ar} is a second [mubtada]{.subs}. It is the [mubtada]{.subs} of the inner sentence.
* [مُتْبِع]{.ar} is the [xabar]{.subs} of the inner sentence. It is also a [mudaf]{.subs}.
* The pronoun [هُ]{.ar} is a [mudafil]{.subs}.
* The inner sentence [الْحِصَانُ مُتْبِعُهُ]{.ar} is the [xabar]{.subs} of the [mubtada]{.subs} ([الْفَارِسُ]{.ar}) of outer sentence.

The [xabar]{.subs} of the inner sentence [مُتْبِع]{.ar} [one who makes tired]{.trans}
has a [mustatir]{.subs} [faa3il]{.subs} pronoun, implicated as [[هُوَ]{.ar}].
It is possible for this [mustatir]{.subs} [faa3il]{.subs} pronoun
to refer to either 
[الْفَارِسُ]{.ar}
or
[الْحِصَانُ]{.ar}.
Let's discuss both these meanings:

 i. If
    the [mustatir]{.subs} [faa3il]{.subs} pronoun [[هُوَ]{.ar}] in
    [مُتْبِع]{.ar} refers to
    [الْحِصَانُ]{.ar}
    then the meaning is that
    [the horse makes the horseman tired]{.trans}.
    In this case, 
    the pronoun [هُ]{.ar} in [مُتْبِعُهُ]{.ar} refers to 
    [الْفَارِسُ]{.ar}.
    
ii. And if 
    the [mustatir]{.subs} [faa3il]{.subs} pronoun [[هُوَ]{.ar}] in
    [مُتْبِع]{.ar} refers to
    [الْفَارِسُ]{.ar}
    then the meaning is that
    [the horseman makes the horse tired]{.trans}.
    In this case, 
    the pronoun [هُ]{.ar} in [مُتْبِعُهُ]{.ar} refers to 
    [الْحِصَانُ]{.ar}.

Both meanings are possible.

If only the second meaning is desired,
then the [mustatir]{.subs} [faa3il]{.subs} pronoun [[هُوَ]{.ar}] can be made [zaahir]{.subs} and added after the [ism_fail]{.subs} [مُتْبِع]{.ar}, thus:

(@) [الفارس الحصانُ مُتْعِبُه **هُوَ**]{.ar}
    [[النحو الوافي]{.ar} 1/464]{.citex}  
    [The horseman -- the horse -- [he] makes him tired.]{.trans}  
    (i.e. [The horseman makes the horse tired.]{.trans})

Now only the second meaning is possible.
If the first meaning is desired, the [faa3il]{.subs} pronoun of 
[مُتْبِع]{.ar}
must stay [mustatir]{.subs} and the ambiguity will remain.

By the way, the ambiguity arose in the original sentence
([الفارس الحصانُ مُتْعِبُه]{.ar})
only because both [mubtada]{.subs}s
([الْفَارِسُ]{.ar}
and
[الْحِصَانُ]{.ar})
are singular masculine nouns.
If the two [mubtada]{.subs}s are distinguishable in number or gender then there will be no ambiguity.
However, even in this case,
according to some grammarians,
if the [xabar]{.subs} is to refer to the [mubtada]{.subs} of the outer sentence,
then the [faa3il]{.subs} pronoun of the [ism_fail]{.subs} in the [xabar]{.subs} should be made [zaahir]{.subs}.
For example:

(@3amal_mush_zaydun_hindun_daaribuhaa_huwa) [زَيْدٌ هِنْدٌ ضَارِبُهَا **هُوَ**]{.ar}
    [[[شرح ابن عقيل على الألفية]{.ar} 1/207](https://shamela.ws/book/9904/206#p1)]{.citex}  
    [Zayd -- Hind -- [he] is beating her.]{.trans}  
    (i.e. [Zayd is beating Hind.]{.trans})

But according to other grammarians, 
because [ضَارِب]{.ar} can refer only to Zayd and not to Hind,
the [ism_fail]{.subs}'s [faa3il]{.subs} pronoun can remain latent,^[[[شرح ابن عقيل على الألفية]{.ar} 1/207](https://shamela.ws/book/9904/206#p1)] thus:

(@) [زَيْدٌ هِنْدٌ ضَارِبُهَا]{.ar}   
    [Zayd -- Hind -- [he] is beating her.]{.trans}  
    (i.e. [Zayd is beating Hind.]{.trans})

<!--
(@) [زَيْدٌ عَمْرٌو ضَارِبُهُ]{.ar}
    [[شرح ابن عقيل على الألفية]{.ar} 1/208]{.citex}  

This sentence can have two different meanings:

 i. [Zayd -- [#eamr]{.trn2} beats him]{.trans}
ii. [Zayd -- [#eamr]{.trn2} beats him]{.trans}
-->

## The [sababi]{.subs} [xabar]{.subs}

<!--
[Zayd beats [#amr]{.trn2}]{.trans}
-->

Consider again example (@3amal_mush_zaydun_yadribu_3amran) [زَيْدٌ يَضْرِبُ عَمْرًا]{.ar}.
From this original sentence, we replaced the verb 
[يَضْرِبُ]{.ar}
with its [ism_fail]{.subs} and came up with
(@3amal_mush_zaydun_daaribun_3amran) [زَيْدٌ ضَارِبٌ عَمْرًا]{.ar}.

Now consider the following example:

(@3amal_mush_zaydun_yadribu_aboohu_3amran) [زَيْدٌ يَضْرِبُ أَبُوهُ عَمْرًا]{.ar}  
    [Zayd -- his father beats [#eamr]{.trn2}]{.trans}

In example (@3amal_mush_zaydun_yadribu_aboohu_3amran) above
the [faa3il]{.subs} of 
[يَضْرِبُ]{.ar}
is not Zayd but Zayd's father.
If we use this sentence as our starting point,
we can again replace the verb
[يَضْرِبُ]{.ar}
with its [ism_fail]{.subs} 
[ضَارِبٌ]{.ar}
and say:

(@3amal_mush_zaydun_daaribun_aboohu_3amran) [زَيْدٌ ضَارِبٌ أَبُوهُ عَمْرًا]{.ar}  
    [Zayd -- his father is beating [#eamr]{.trn2}]{.trans}

[أَبُوهُ]{.ar} is the ([zaahir]{.subs}) [faa3il]{.subs} of the [ism_fail]{.subs}
[ضَارِبٌ]{.ar}.
And [عَمْرًا]{.ar} is its [mafulb]{.subs}.
So just like a verb can have an [zaahir]{.subs} noun as its [faa3il]{.subs} instead of a [mustatir]{.subs} pronoun,
so too can the [ism_fail]{.subs} have an [zaahir]{.subs} noun as its [faa3il]{.subs} instead of a [mustatir]{.subs} pronoun.

Again, there is one important difference between using the verb
[يَضْرِبُ]{.ar}
vs using its [ism_fail]{.subs} 
[ضَارِبٌ]{.ar}.
And that is that 
[يَضْرِبُ أَبُوهُ عَمْرًا]{.ar}
in example (@3amal_mush_zaydun_yadribu_aboohu_3amran)
is a complete sentence.
This inner sentence is the [xabar]{.subs} of the outer sentence.
Therefore, example (@3amal_mush_zaydun_yadribu_aboohu_3amran) is a compound sentence.

However,
[ضَارِبٌ أَبُوهُ عَمْرًا]{.ar}
in example (@3amal_mush_zaydun_daaribun_aboohu_3amran) 
is not a complete sentence.
[ضَارِبٌ]{.ar}
itself, as a single word, is the [xabar]{.subs} of the [mubtada]{.subs} [زَيْدٌ]{.ar}.^[[[مختصر المعاني للتفتازاني]{.ar} 86](https://ketabonline.com/ar/books/16360/read?part=1&page=82&index=72272/72275)]
So example (@3amal_mush_zaydun_daaribun_aboohu_3amran) [زَيْدٌ ضَارِبٌ أَبُوهُ عَمْرًا]{.ar}
is not a compound sentence.

<!--
In example () it is an inner sentence as the [xabar]{.subs} of the outer sentence.
Therefore () zaydun yaDrib abuuhu 3amran is a compound sentence.
But DAribun abuuhu 3amran is not a complete sentence by itself.
Rather DAribun comprises the [xabar]{.subs} as a single word.^[subki, mukhtasar al-ma3aani lil-taftaazaani 86]
So () zaydun DAribun aBuuhu 3amran is not a compound sentence.
-->

The [xabar]{.subs} [ضَارِبٌ]{.ar} in example (@3amal_mush_zaydun_daaribun_aboohu_3amran) [زَيْدٌ ضَارِبٌ أَبُوهُ عَمْرًا]{.ar}
is called a [sababi]{.subs} [xabar]{.subs}.^[[[الخبر السببي لوجيهة السطل]{.ar}](https://alababmisr.com/%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%AE%D8%A8%D8%B1-%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%B3%D8%A8%D8%A8%D9%8A-%D8%AF-%D9%88%D8%AC%D9%8A%D9%87%D8%A9-%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%B3%D8%B7%D9%84/); [[الأشباه والنظائر للسيوطي]{.ar} 4/287](https://lib.eshia.ir/71585/4/287)]
A [mushtaqq]{.subs} noun is termed _[sababi]{.subs}_ when it governs a [faa3il]{.subs} which is annexed to a pronoun that refers back to the original referent of the [mushtaqq]{.subs} noun.^[[[شرح ألفية ابن مالك للشاطبي]{.ar} 4/404](https://shamela.ws/book/20562/2393) (also cited by [الضمير المستتر لسعود بن عبيد الله الصاعدي]{.ar} 161)]
In our example, the
[mushtaqq]{.subs} noun [ضَارِبٌ]{.ar}
governs a [faa3il]{.subs}
[أَب]{.ar}
which is annexed to a pronoun [هُ]{.ar}
that refers back to the original referent of the [mushtaqq]{.subs} noun,
the [mubtada]{.subs}
[زَيْد]{.ar}.


<!--
This can be made clear by looking at the following example:

(@) kaana zaydun muntaliqan

-->

### Varying the number or gender of the [zaahir]{.subs} [faa3il]{.subs} of the [sababi]{.subs} [xabar]{.subs}

Here is another example of a sentence with a [sababi]{.subs} [xabar]{.subs}:

(@3amal_mush_kaana_zaydun_muntaliqan_aboohu) [كَانَ زَيْدٌ مُنْطَلِقًا أَبُوهُ]{.ar}
    [Peled, _Sentence types_ 208]{.citex}  
    [Zayd -- his father was setting out.]{.trans}

In example (@3amal_mush_kaana_zaydun_muntaliqan_aboohu) 
above,
[مُنْطَلِقًا]{.ar} is the [sababi]{.subs} [xabar]{.subs} of [كَانَ]{.ar}.
The [zaahir]{.subs} [faa3il]{.subs} of the [مُنْطَلِقًا]{.ar} is the singular masculine noun [أَبُوه]{.ar} [his father]{.trans}.

Let's see what happens when
we vary the number or gender of this [zaahir]{.subs} [faa3il]{.subs} of the [sababi]{.subs} [xabar]{.subs}.

(@3amal_mush_kaana_alzaydaani_muntaliqan_abawaahuma) [كَانَ الزَيْدَانِ **مُنْطَلِقًا** أَبَوَاهُمَا]{.ar}
    [Peled, _Sentence types_ 208]{.citex}  
    [The two Zayds -- their fathers were setting out.]{.trans}

In example (@3amal_mush_kaana_alzaydaani_muntaliqan_abawaahuma) above,
the [sababi]{.subs} [xabar]{.subs} 
[مُنْطَلِقًا]{.ar}
remains in the singular, 
even though its [faa3il]{.subs} is the dual
[أَبَوَاهُمَا]{.ar}.

This is analagous to a verb, which remains in the singular for dual and plural [faa3il]{.subs}s.
For example
[كَانَ الزَيْدَانِ **يَنْطَلِقُ** أَبَوَاهُمَا]{.ar}, etc.

If the gender of the [ism_fail]{.subs}'s [faa3il]{.subs} is feminine,
then the [ism_fail]{.subs} remains in the singular but it is feminized.
For example:

(@) [زَيْدٌ **مُنْطَلِقَةٌ** أُمُّهُ]{.ar}  
    [Zayd -- his mother is setting out.]{.trans}

(@) [كَانَتْ هِنْدٌ **مُنْطَلِقَةً** خَالَتَاهَا]{.ar}  
    [Hind -- her two maternal aunts were setting out.]{.trans}

This again is analagous to the feminizing a verb that has a feminine [faa3il]{.subs}.

If the [faa3il]{.subs} of the [ism_fail]{.subs} is a plural, then we have an choice:

If the [ism_fail]{.subs} has a sound plural, then, again, it is not used and the [ism_fail]{.subs} remains in the singular.
For example:

(@) [كَانَ الزَيْدُونَ **مُنْطَلِقًا** آبَاؤُهُمْ]{.ar}  
    [The Zayds -- their fathers were setting out.]{.trans}

(@) [زَيْدٌ **مُنْطَلِقَةٌ** خَالَاتُهُ]{.ar}  
    [Zayd -- his maternal aunts are setting out.]{.trans}

But if
the [ism_fail]{.subs} has a broken plural, then it is allowed to be used, and is indeed preferred,^[[البسيط لابن أبي الربيع]{.ar} 693--694 cited by Peled, _Sentence types_ 208 (footnote)]
when the [faa3il]{.subs} is a plural.

For example:

(@) [كَانَ الزَّيْدُونَ **قِيَامًا** آبَاؤُهُمْ]{.ar}  
    [The Zayds -- their fathers were standing]{.trans}

Here are some examples of [sababi]{.subs} [xabar]{.subs}s from the [#qurEAn]{.trn2}:

(@3amal_mush_aathimun_qalbuhu) [فَإِنَّهُۥۤ **ءَاثِمࣱ** قَلۡبُهُۥۗ]{.quran}
    [[[سورة البقرة]{.ar} 2:283](https://quran.com/2/283)]{.citex}  
    [his heart is indeed sinful]{.trans}  
    (Other analyses besides a [sababi]{.subs} [xabar]{.subs} are also possible.^[[[الدر المصون للسمين الحلبي]{.ar}](https://tafsir.app/aldur-almasoon/2/283) for [سورة البقرة]{.ar} 2:283] One such differing analysis is discussed in section\ (ref) below.)

(@) [وَظَنُّوۤا۟ أَنَّهُم **مَّانِعَتُهُمۡ** حُصُونُهُم مِّنَ ٱللَّهِ]{.quran}
    [[[سورة الحشر]{.ar} 59:2](https://quran.com/59/2)]{.citex}  
    [and they thought that their fortresses would protect them from Allāh]{.trans}  
    (Another analysis is also possible: [حُصُونُهُمْ]{.ar} can be a [mubtada]{.subs}, and [مَانِعَتُهُمْ]{.ar} is its fronted [xabar]{.subs}.^[[[الدر المصون للسمين الحلبي]{.ar}](https://tafsir.app/aldur-almasoon/59/2) for [سورة الحشر]{.ar} 59:2])

### Word order of the [faa3il]{.subs} and the [mafulb]{.subs} in a [sababi]{.subs} [xabar]{.subs}

If the [ism_fail]{.subs} is transitive, then the normal word order is [ism_fail]{.subs}, [faa3il]{.subs}, [mafulb]{.subs}.
For example:

(@) [هَذَا ضَارب أَبوهُ زيدا]{.ar}
    [[الهمع للسيوطي]{.ar} 3/89]{.citex}  
    [This [person] -- his father is beating Zayd.]{.trans}  

But the [mafulb]{.subs} can be made to precede the [faa3il]{.subs} thus:

(@) [هذا ضارب زيدا أبوه]{.ar}
    [[[حاشية الصبان على شرح الأشمونى لألفية ابن مالك]{.ar} 2/453](https://shamela.ws/book/11539/883)]{.citex}  
    [This [person] -- his father is beating Zayd.]{.trans}  

## The [sababi]{.subs} [na3t]{.subs}

In section\ (ref) above we have seen how a [ism_fail]{.subs} can govern a [zaahir]{.subs} [faa3il]{.subs} when it is a [sababi]{.subs} [xabar]{.subs}.
In a similar manner,
a [ism_fail]{.subs} can govern a [zaahir]{.subs} [faa3il]{.subs} when it is a [sababi]{.subs} [na3t]{.subs}.

Consider the following example:

(@) [مَرَرْتُ بِرَجُلٍ مُنْطَلِقٍ أَبُوهُ]{.ar}  
    [I passed by a man whose father is setting out]{.trans}

The [ism_fail]{.subs} 
[مُنْطَلِقٍ]{.ar}
is a [na3t]{.subs} of the [manut]{.subs}
[رَجُلٍ]{.ar}.
Because it is a [sababi]{.subs} [na3t]{.subs},
it has a [faa3il]{.subs}
[أَب]{.ar}
that is annexed to a pronoun
[هُ]{.ar}
which refers to the [manut]{.subs}
[رَجُلٍ]{.ar}.

We know that,
in general,
a [na3t]{.subs} will match its [manut]{.subs} in four aspects:

  i. state
 ii. definiteness
iii. gender
 iv. number (singular/dual/plural)

The [sababi]{.subs} [na3t]{.subs} will also match its preceding [manut]{.subs}
in state and definiteness.
(You can see the [na3t]{.subs}
[مُنْطَلِقٍ]{.ar}
matches its [manut]{.subs}
[رَجُلٍ]{.ar}
in the [istate]{.subs} and in being indefinite.)
But in matching gender and number the [sababi]{.subs} [na3t]{.subs} has different rules.
Consistent with we learned for the [sababi]{.subs} [xabar]{.subs} above,
the [sababi]{.subs} [na3t]{.subs} will, in general, always be singular,
and it will match its [faa3il]{.subs} in gender.
Here are some examples that show different combinations:

(@) [مَرَرْتُ بِالرَّجُلِ الْمُنْطَلِقِ أَبُوهُ]{.ar}  
    [I passed by the man whose father is setting out.]{.trans}

(@) [مَرَرْتُ بِرَجُلٍ مُنْطَلِقٍ أَخَوَاهُ]{.ar}  
    [I passed by a man whose two brothers are setting out.]{.trans}

(@) [رَأَيْتُ رِجَالًا مُنْطَلِقًا آبَاؤُهُمْ]{.ar}  
    [I saw men whose fathers are setting out.]{.trans}

(@) [رَأَيْتُ رَجُلًا مُنْطَلِقَةً أُمُّهُ]{.ar}  
    [I saw a man whose mother is setting out.]{.trans}

(@) [جَاءَنِي زَيْدٌ الْمُنْطَلِقَةُ أَخَوَاتُهُ]{.ar}  
    [Zayd whose sisters are setting out came to me.]{.trans}

(@) [جَاءَتْنِي امْرَأَةٌ مُنْطَلِقٌ أَبُوهَا]{.ar}  
    [A woman whose father is setting out came to me.]{.trans}

(@) [مَرَرْتُ بِالْمَرْأَةِ الْمُنْطَلِقِ أَخَوَاهَا]{.ar}  
    [I passed by the woman whose two brothers are setting out.]{.trans}

The above examples use the [ism_fail]{.subs}
[مُنْطَلِق]{.ar}
which only has sound plurals.
Therefore it remains in the singular.
If an [ism_fail]{.subs} has a broken plural, it is permitted (and in fact preferred) to use the broken plural for a plural [faa3il]{.subs}.^[[[شرح قطر الندى وبل الصدى]{.ar} 288](https://shamela.ws/book/6970/263); [النحو الوافي]{.ar} 3/453--454]
Examples:

(@) [مَرَرْت بِرِجَال قيام آباؤهم]{.ar}
    [[[شرح قطر الندى وبل الصدى]{.ar} 288](https://shamela.ws/book/6970/263)]{.citex}  
    [I passed by men whose fathers are standing.]{.trans}  

(@) [مَرَرْت برجل قعُود غلمانه]{.ar}
    [[[شرح قطر الندى وبل الصدى]{.ar} 288](https://shamela.ws/book/6970/263)]{.citex}  
    [I passed by a man whose slave-boys are sitting]{.trans}  
    (Note that the [manut]{.subs} [رَجُل]{.ar} is singular in this case.)

## The [ism_fail]{.subs} as the governor of a non-[sababi]{.subs} [zaahir]{.subs} [faa3il]{.subs}

When the [faa3il]{.subs} of the [ism_fail]{.subs} is [zaahir]{.subs} then it will often be a [sababi]{.subs} [faa3il]{.subs},
as we have seen in sections\ (sababi-xabar) and (sababi-na3t) above.
However, it is also possible for the [ism_fail]{.subs} to govern a non-[sababi]{.subs} [zaahir]{.subs} [faa3il]{.subs}.
For example:

(@) [مررت برجل متكلمٍ محمدٌ في داره]{.ar}
    [[البسيط لابن أبي الربيع]{.ar} 1075]{.citex}  
    [I passed by a man [whom] [#muHammad]{.trn2} was speaking in his house.]{.ar}

In the example above
[محمد]{.ar}
is the [faa3il]{.subs} of the [ism_fail]{.subs}
[متكلم]{.ar}.
But because it is not annexed to a pronoun which refers back to
[رجل]{.ar},
therefore it is not a [sababi]{.subs} [faa3il]{.subs}.

## Conditions for the [ism_fail]{.subs} to govern a [faa3il]{.subs}

In section\ (ref) above,
we discussed the
conditions for the [ism_fail]{.subs} to govern a [mafulb]{.subs}.
Correspondingly, there exist
conditions for the [ism_fail]{.subs} to govern a [faa3il]{.subs}.

The [ism_fail]{.subs} can have either an [zaahir]{.subs} [faa3il]{.subs} (either as a noun or as a pronoun),
or a [mustatir]{.subs} [faa3il]{.subs} pronoun.
We will treat each of these separately below:

### Conditions for the [ism_fail]{.subs} to govern an [zaahir]{.subs} [faa3il]{.subs}

The grammarians differed with regard to the
conditions under which the [ism_fail]{.subs} is allowed to govern an [zaahir]{.subs} [faa3il]{.subs}.
According to some, the same conditions are applicable as for governing a [mafulb]{.subs},
namely that 
when an [ism_fail]{.subs} is not defined by [ٱل]{.ar},
then
it can only govern an [zaahir]{.subs} [faa3il]{.subs} when 

 i. It has an imperfect aspect.
ii. It has [i3timaad]{.subs}

So it is not allowed to govern an [zaahir]{.subs} [faa3il]{.subs} for a perfect aspect.
The following example would then be disallowed:

(@) [x]{.subs} [زَيْدٌ قَائِمٌ أَبُوهُ أَمْسِ]{.ar}
    [[الضمير المستتر لسعود بن عبيد الله الصاعدي]{.ar} 134]{.citex}  
    [Zayd -- his father stood yesterday.]{.trans}

Other grammarians, however, allowed such a sentence.^[[الضمير المستتر لسعود بن عبيد الله الصاعدي]{.ar} 134]

when an [ism_fail]{.subs} is defined by [ٱل]{.ar},
then
it can only govern an [zaahir]{.subs} [faa3il]{.subs} unconditionally.
So it can govern with perfective aspect and without [i3timaad]{.subs}.
Examples:

(@) [جاءني القائم أبوه]{.ar}
    [[[شرح ألفية ابن مالك للشاطبي]{.ar} 1/449](https://shamela.ws/book/20562/449)]{.citex}  
    [The one whose father is standing came.]{.trans}  

(@) [القائم أبوه ضاحك]{.ar}
    [[[التذييل والتكميل لأبي حيان]{.ar} 3/257](https://shamela.ws/book/17116/917#p1)]{.citex}  
    [The one whose father is standing is laughing.]{.trans}  

(@) [جاء الضارب أبوه زيدًا أمس]{.ar}
    [[[شرح ابن الناظم على ألفية ابن مالك]{.ar} 59](https://shamela.ws/book/18115/57)]{.citex}  
    [The one whose father beat Zayd yesterday came.]{.trans}  



### Conditions for the [ism_fail]{.subs} to govern a [mustatir]{.subs} [faa3il]{.subs} pronoun

As a default,
the [ism_fail]{.subs} requires
a [mustatir]{.subs} [faa3il]{.subs} pronoun.
So it governs
a [mustatir]{.subs} [faa3il]{.subs} pronoun unconditionally, except when it is prevented from doing so because of one of the following situations:

#### The [ism_fail]{.subs} is already governing an [zaahir]{.subs} [faa3il]{.subs} noun {.unnumbered}

If the [ism_fail]{.subs} is already governing an [zaahir]{.subs} [faa3il]{.subs},
then it will not also have a [mustatir]{.subs} [faa3il]{.subs} pronoun.
This is because one [ism_fail]{.subs} cannot have two [faa3il]{.subs}s.^[[الضمير المستتر لسعود بن عبيد الله الصاعدي]{.ar} 139]
Example:

(@) [زَيْدٌ قَائِمٌ أَبُوهُ]{.ar}
    [[الضمير المستتر لسعود بن عبيد الله الصاعدي]{.ar} 139]{.citex}  
    [Zayd -- his father is standing]{.trans}

Beware though, that sometimes it may appear that an [ism_fail]{.subs} is governing an [zaahir]{.subs} [faa3il]{.subs},
but actually another interpretation may also be possible.
Consider the following [ayah]{.subs} that we discussed in section\ (ref) above:

(@3amal_mush_aathimun_qalbuhu) [فَإِنَّهُۥۤ **ءَاثِمࣱ** قَلۡبُهُۥۗ]{.quran}
    [[[سورة البقرة]{.ar} 2:283](https://quran.com/2/283)]{.citex}  
    [his heart is indeed sinful]{.trans}

We had discussed this as a case of a [sababi]{.subs} [xabar]{.subs}.
But another analysis is also possible:
The [ism_fail]{.subs} [آثِمٌ]{.ar} is governing a [mustatir]{.subs} [faa3il]{.subs} pronoun, and
[قَلْبُهُ]{.ar} is a [badal]{.subs} for the [mustatir]{.subs} [faa3il]{.subs} pronoun.^[[[الدر المصون للسمين الحلبي]{.ar}](https://tafsir.app/aldur-almasoon/2/283) for [سورة البقرة]{.ar} 2:283]

#### The [ism_fail]{.subs} is already governing an [zaahir]{.subs} [faa3il]{.subs} pronoun {.unnumbered}

We discussed in section\ (ref) above, a situation in which the originally [mustatir]{.subs} [faa3il]{.subs} pronoun of a [ism_fail]{.subs} becomes [zaahir]{.subs}.
Because the [faa3il]{.subs} is now [zaahir]{.subs} the [ism_fail]{.subs} will not govern an additional [mustatir]{.subs} [faa3il]{.subs}.^[[الضمير المستتر لسعود بن عبيد الله الصاعدي]{.ar} 144]

(@3amal_mush_zaydun_hindun_daaribuhaa_huwa) [زَيْدٌ هِنْدٌ ضَارِبُهَا هُوَ]{.ar}
    [[[شرح ابن عقيل على الألفية]{.ar} 1/207](https://shamela.ws/book/9904/206#p1)]{.citex}  
    [Zayd -- Hind -- [he] is beating her.]{.trans}  
    (i.e. [Zayd is beating Hind.]{.trans})

<!--
#### The [ism_fail]{.subs} is the [mudaf]{.subs} in a [ma3nawi]{.subs} [idaafah]{.subs} {.unnumbered}

When [ism_fail]{.subs} is the [mudaf]{.subs} in a [ma3nawi]{.subs} [idaafah]{.subs},
then it will not govern a [mustatir]{.subs} [faa3il]{.subs} pronoun.^[[الضمير المستتر لسعود بن عبيد الله الصاعدي]{.ar} 142]
This can happen when the [ism_fail]{.subs} indicates a perfective aspect.
We saw an example of this in the conditions for governing a [mafulb]{.subs} above:

   [[شرح ابن عقيل على الألفية]{.ar} 3/106]{.citex}

When the [ism_fail]{.subs} does not verbal force, then it does not govern a [mustatir]{.subs} [faa3il]{.subs} pronoun.^[See citations in [الضمير المستتر لسعود بن عبيد الله الصاعدي]{.ar} 154].

For example:

(@) [مَرَرْتُ بِرَجُلٍ قَائِمٍ لَا قَاعِدٍ]{.ar}
    [[الضمير المستتر لسعود بن عبيد الله الصاعدي]{.ar} 156]{.citex}

## [#lafzi]{.subs} [idaafah]{.subs}

#### [#lafzi]{.subs} [idaafah]{.subs} used to eliminate [tanwin]{.subs} {.unnumbered}

Consider again the sentence:

(@3amal_mush_zaydun_daaribun_3amran) [زَيْدٌ ضَارِبٌ عَمْرًا]{.ar}  
    [zaydun DAribun 3amran]{.trn}  
    [Zayd is beating [#amr]{.trn2}]{.trans}

The [ism_fail]{.subs} 
[ضَارِبٌ]{.ar}
has a [tanwin]{.subs} which is pronounced before pronouncing the [mafulb]{.subs}
[عَمْرًا]{.ar}.
In an effort to make the pronunciation easier, this [tanwin]{.subs} is often eliminated and replaced with an [idaafah]{.subs}.
The [mafulb]{.subs} is then made into a [mudafil]{.subs} in the [istate]{.subs}.
The meaning remains the same.
So the above sentence then becomes:

(@) [زَيْدٌ ضَارِبُ عَمْرٍو]{.ar}  
    [zaydun DAribu 3amrin]{.trn}  
    [Zayd is beating [#amr]{.trn2}]{.trans}

This is called a [lafzi]{.subs} [idaafah]{.subs}, 
as opposed to a [ma3nawi]{.subs} [idaafah]{.subs},
which is what we have been studying so far.
This is because it is only an [idaafah]{.subs} for the purposes of easing the pronunciation,
not in meaning.

Regarding terminology,
[عَمْرٍو]{.ar}
syntactically
becomes a [mudafil]{.subs} in the [lafzi]{.subs} [idaafah]{.subs}.
But in meaning, it is still the [mafulb]{.subs} of the [ism_fail]{.subs}
[ضَارِب]{.ar}.
We will refer to it as the _semantic [mafulb]{.subs}_.

By the way, the sentence
[زَيْدٌ ضَارِبُ عَمْرٍو]{.ar}
can also be a [ma3nawi]{.subs} [idaafah]{.subs}.
In which case, the meaning will be:
[Zayd is the beater of [#eamr]{.trn2}]{.trans}.
So if we come across such a sentence, how can we tell if it is a [ma3nawi]{.subs} [idaafah]{.subs} or a [lafzi]{.subs} [idaafah]{.subs}?
The answer is, in this case, context should guide us.
We will see below that the [lafzi]{.subs} [idaafah]{.subs} is not always identical in form to the [ma3nawi]{.subs} [idaafah]{.subs}.
So in those cases, the form of the [idaafah]{.subs} will tell us whether 
it is a [ma3nawi]{.subs} [idaafah]{.subs} or a [lafzi]{.subs} [idaafah]{.subs}.

Here are some more examples of a [lafzi]{.subs} [idaafah]{.subs} used to eliminate a [tanwin]{.subs}:

(@) [الْهِنْدَاتُ ضارباتُ عمرٍو]{.ar}
    [modified from [[شرح التصريح على التوضيح]{.ar} 1/682](https://shamela.ws/book/9985/694)]{.citex}  
    [The Hinds are beating [#eamr]{.trn2}]{.trans}  
    (instead of [ضارباتٌ عمرًا]{.ar})

When the [ism_fail]{.subs} is a [diptote]{.subs}, it will not have a [tanwin]{.subs}.
But the [lafzi]{.subs} [idaafah]{.subs} may still be used in such a case because a [tanwin]{.subs} would have been present if the word were [triptote]{.subs}.^[[[شرح التصريح على التوضيح]{.ar} 1/682](https://shamela.ws/book/9985/694)]
For example:

(@) [الْهِنْدَاتُ ضواربُ عَمْرٍو]{.ar}
    [modified from [[شرح التصريح على التوضيح]{.ar} 1/682](https://shamela.ws/book/9985/694)]{.citex}  
    [The Hinds are beating [#eamr]{.trn2}]{.trans}  
    (instead of [ضواربُ عمرًا]{.ar})

#### [#lafzi]{.subs} [idaafah]{.subs} used to eliminate the [ن]{.ar} of a dual or plural suffix {.unnumbered}

The [lafzi]{.subs} [idaafah]{.subs} is used in situations when the governing [ism_fail]{.subs} has [tanwin]{.subs} (as above),
and also in situations when it ends with a [ن]{.ar} arising from a dual or sound plural.
Examples:

(@) [الزَّيْدَانِ ضاربا عَمْرٍو]{.ar}
    [modified from [[شرح التصريح على التوضيح]{.ar} 1/682](https://shamela.ws/book/9985/694)]{.citex}  
    [The [two] Zayds are beating [#eamr]{.trn2}]{.trans}  
    (instead of [ضاربانِ عَمْرًا]{.ar})

#### Definiteness of the [lafzi]{.subs} [idaafah]{.subs} {.unnumbered}

Because this is a [lafzi]{.subs} and not a [ma3nawi]{.subs} [idaafah]{.subs},
the [mudaf]{.subs} 
is not made definite  by a definite [mudafil]{.subs}.
In the examples so far, the [mudafil]{.subs}s have been proper nouns 
([زَيْد]{.ar}, [عَمْرو]{.ar})
which are definite.
But the [ism_fail]{.subs}s
([ضَارِب]{.ar},
[ضَارِبَا]{.ar},
etc.)
remain indefinite, because they did not originally have [ٱل]{.ar} when governing a [mafulb]{.subs}.
This example proves the above claim:

(@3amal_mush_hadyan_baaligha_lka3bati) [هَدۡیَۢا بَـٰلِغَ ٱلۡكَعۡبَةِ]{.quran}
    [[[سورة المائدة]{.ar} 5:95](https://quran.com/5/95) cited by [[شرح ابن يعيش على المفصل]{.ar} 4/84](https://shamela.ws/book/13301/1448)]{.citex}  
    [as an offering [to Allāh] delivered to the Kaʿbah]{.trans}

In  example (@3amal_mush_hadyan_baaligha_lka3bati) above,
the [ism_fail]{.subs}
[بَالِغ]{.ar} is a [mudaf]{.subs} to the definite [mudafil]{.subs} [الْكَعْبَة]{.ar}.
But this is a [lafzi]{.subs} [idaafah]{.subs}. So
[بَالِغ]{.ar}
does not become definite.
Therefore 
[بَالِغ]{.ar}
can be a [na3t]{.subs} to the indefinite 
[هَدْيًا]{.ar}.

If the [ism_fail]{.subs} is to be made definite in a [lafzi]{.subs} [idaafah]{.subs} then a [ٱل]{.ar} is added to it.
For example:

(@) [هذان الضاربا زيدٍ]{.ar}
    [[[شرح ابن يعيش على المفصل]{.ar} 2/132](https://shamela.ws/book/13301/582#p1)]{.citex}  
    [These two are the beaters of Zayd.]{.trans}  
    (instead of [هذان الضاربان زيدًا]{.ar})

(@) [وَٱلۡمُقِیمِی ٱلصَّلَوٰةِ]{.quran}
    [[[سورة الحج]{.ar} 22:35](https://quran.com/22/35) cited by [[شرح ابن يعيش على المفصل]{.ar} 2/132](https://shamela.ws/book/13301/582#p1)]{.citex}  
    [and the establishers of prayer]{.trans}

Adding [ٱل]{.ar} to the [mudaf]{.subs} is particular to a [lafzi]{.subs} [idaafah]{.subs}.
As we know, it is not permitted in a [ma3nawi]{.subs} [idaafah]{.subs}.
So when we see
[ٱل]{.ar} with a [mudaf]{.subs}, then we will know that the [idaafah]{.subs} has to be a [lafzi]{.subs} one.

#### When the [ism_fail]{.subs} does not have [tanwin]{.subs} or a suffixed [ن]{.ar} {.unnumbered}

Consider the following case of a [ism_fail]{.subs} governing a [mafulb]{.subs}:

(@) [الضَّارِبُ زَيْدًا]{.ar}  
    [the beater of Zayd]{.trans}  

There is no [tanwin]{.subs} of suffixed [ن]{.ar} after the [ism_fail]{.subs}.
Therefore, a [lafzi]{.subs} [idaafah]{.subs} is not permitted, and we cannot say:

(@) [x]{.subs} [الضَّارِبُ زَيْدٍ]{.ar}
    [[[شرح ابن يعيش على المفصل]{.ar} 2/132](https://shamela.ws/book/13301/582#p1)]{.citex}  

The following are similarly not permitted:

(@) [x]{.subs} [الضارب رجلٍ]{.ar}
    [[[شرح ابن عقيل على الألفية]{.ar} 3/47](https://shamela.ws/book/9904/726)]{.citex}  
    [the beater of the man]{.trans}  

(@) [x]{.subs} [الضَّارِبُ عَبْدِ زَيْدٍ]{.ar}
    [Wright 2/66B]{.citex}
    [the beater of the slave of Zayd]{.trans}  

(@) [x]{.subs} [الضَّارِبُ عَبْدِهِ]{.ar}
    [Wright 2/66B]{.citex}
    [the beater of his slave]{.trans}  

If, however, the [mafulb]{.subs} is defined by [ٱل]{.ar},
or is itself a [mudaf]{.subs} to a [mudafil]{.subs}
that is defined by [ٱل]{.ar},
then,
as an exception,
the [lafzi]{.subs} [idaafah]{.subs} is again permitted.^[Wright 2/66A]
For example:

(@) [الضَّارِبُ الْعَبْدِ]{.ar}
    [Wright 2/66A]{.citex}  
    [the beater of the slave]{.trans}  

(@) [الضَّارِبُ رَأْسِ الْعَبْدِ]{.ar}
    [Wright 2/66A]{.citex}  
    [the beater of the head of the slave]{.trans}  

<!--
We will also see in section\ (ref), [ia]{.subs}, that when the governor is used with a [sifah]{.subs} meaning,
then too such a [lafzi]{.subs} [idaafah]{.subs} is permitted.^[[[شرح ابن يعيش على المفصل]{.ar} 2/132--133](https://shamela.ws/book/13301/582#p1)]
For example:
-->

(@) [الضَّارِبُ الرَّجُلِ]{.ar}
    [[[شرح ابن يعيش على المفصل]{.ar} 2/132](https://shamela.ws/book/13301/582#p1)]{.citex}  
    [the beater of the man]{.trans}

(@) [الضَّوَارِبُ/الضُّرَّابُ/الضَّارِبَاتُ الرَّجُلِ]{.ar}
    [[[شرح ابن عقيل على الألفية]{.ar} 3/47](https://shamela.ws/book/9904/726)]{.citex}  
    [the beaters of the man]{.trans}

(@) [الضَّوَارِبُ/الضُّرَّابُ/الضَّارِبَاتُ غُلَامِ الرَّجُلِ]{.ar}
    [[[شرح ابن عقيل على الألفية]{.ar} 3/47](https://shamela.ws/book/9904/726)]{.citex}  
    [the beaters of the slave-boy of the man]{.trans}

#### Two or more [mafulb]{.subs}s connected by [وَ]{.ar} or [أَوْ]{.ar} {.unnumbered}

When a [ism_fail]{.subs} governs two or more [mafulb]{.subs}s connected by [وَ]{.ar} or [أَوْ]{.ar}
then, if the first is in a [lafzi]{.subs} [idaafah]{.subs} then the second may either be in the [istate]{.subs} or the [astate]{.subs}.
For example

(@) [هذا ضاربُ زيدٍ وعمرٍو/وعمرًا]{.ar}
    [[[شرح ابن يعيش على المفصل]{.ar} 4/81](https://shamela.ws/book/13301/1445)]{.citex}  
    [This [person] is beating Zayd and [#eamr]{.trn2}]{.trans}  

By the way, if the first [mafulb]{.subs} is in the [astate]{.subs}, then it is not an [idaafah]{.subs} and the second [mafulb]{.subs} would follow in the [astate]{.subs}.

(@) [هذا ضاربٌ زيدًا وعمرًا]{.ar}  
    [This [person] is beating Zayd and [#eamr]{.trn2}]{.trans}  

#### [#lafzi]{.subs} [idaafah]{.subs} with a [zaahir]{.subs} [faa3il]{.subs} {.unnumbered}

Consider an [ism_fail]{.subs} that has a [zaahir]{.subs} [faa3il]{.subs} and is governing a [mafulb]{.subs} thus:

<!--
(@) [هَذَا ضَارب أَبوهُ زيدا]{.ar}
    [[الهمع للسيوطي]{.ar} 3/89]{.citex}  
    [This [person] -- his father is beating Zayd.]{.trans}  
-->

(@) [مررت برجل ضارب أبوه زيدا]{.ar}
    [[[شرح كتاب سيبويه للسيرافي]{.ar} 2/458](https://shamela.ws/book/17726/956)]{.citex}  
    [I passed by a man whose father [was] beating Zayd.]{.trans}  

If we wish to use a [lafzi]{.subs} [idaafah]{.subs}, then the [ism_fail]{.subs} can only be annexed to its [mafulb]{.subs} and not to its [faa3il]{.subs}.
So we can say:

(@) [مررت برجل ضارب زيد أبوه]{.ar}
    [[[شرح كتاب سيبويه للسيرافي]{.ar} 2/74](https://shamela.ws/book/17726/572)]{.citex}  
    [I passed by a man whose father [was] beating Zayd.]{.trans}  
    (Remember from section\ (ref) above that the word order [ضَارِبٌ زَيْدًا أَبُوهُ]{.ar} is permissible.)
   
We cannot say:

(@) [x]{.subs} [مررت برجل ضارب أَبِيهِ زيدا]{.ar}
    [[[التذييل والتكميل لأبي حيان]{.ar} 10/359](https://shamela.ws/book/17116/3534)]{.citex}

## The [ism_fail]{.subs} with a pronoun as its [mafulb]{.subs}

When the [ism_fail]{.subs} governs a [mafulb]{.subs} that is a pronoun,
there is considerable variation seen

One possibility is is to separate the [ism_fail]{.subs} from its [maful]{.subs} pronoun using the prefix [إِيَّا]{.ar}, thus:

(@) [ضَارِبٌ إِيَّاكَ]{.ar}
    [[شرح الرضي على الكافية]{.ar} 2/434]{.citex}  
    [beating you]{.trans}  

(@) [الضَارِبُ إِيَّاكَ]{.ar}
    [[شرح الرضي على الكافية]{.ar} 2/434]{.citex}  
    [the beater of you]{.trans}  

(@) [الضَارِبُونَ إِيَّاهُ]{.ar}
    [Wright 2/67A]{.citex}  
    [the beaters of me]{.trans}  

The second possibility, and by far the more common usage, is to use a [lafzi]{.subs} [idaafah]{.subs}, thus:

(@) [ضَارِبُكَ]{.ar}
    [[شرح الرضي على الكافية]{.ar} 2/434]{.citex}  
    [beating you]{.trans}  

(@) [الضَارِبُكَ]{.ar}
    [[شرح الرضي على الكافية]{.ar} 2/434]{.citex}  
    [the beater of you]{.trans}  

(@) [الضارِبِي]{.ar}
    [[[شرح ابن يعيش على المفصل]{.ar} 2/135](https://shamela.ws/book/13301/585#p1)]{.citex}  
    [the beater of me]{.trans}

(@) [الضارباتِي]{.ar}
    [[[شرح ابن يعيش على المفصل]{.ar} 2/135](https://shamela.ws/book/13301/585#p1)]{.citex}  
    [the beaters~f~ of me]{.trans}

When the [ism_fail]{.subs} has a [zaahir]{.subs} [faa3il]{.subs}, then it will follow the attached pronoun, thus:

(@) [هَذَا ضَارِبِي أَبُوهُ]{.ar}  
    [This [person] -- his father is beating me.]{.trans}  

For the dual and sound [Un]{.trn} plural in a [lafzi]{.subs} [idaafah]{.subs}, the [ن]{.ar} of the suffix is regularly deleted.
So we will say:

(@) [هذان ضارباك]{.ar}
    [[[شرح كتاب سيبويه للسيرافي]{.ar} 1/196](https://shamela.ws/book/17726/194)]{.citex}  
    [These two are beating you.]{.trans}  
    (from [ضاربان]{.ar})

(@) [هؤلاء ضاربوك]{.ar}
    [[[شرح كتاب سيبويه للسيرافي]{.ar} 1/196](https://shamela.ws/book/17726/194)]{.citex}  
    [These [persons] are beating you.]{.trans}  
    (from [ضاربون]{.ar})

(@) [الضارِباك]{.ar}
    [[[شرح ابن يعيش على المفصل]{.ar} 2/135](https://shamela.ws/book/13301/585#p1)]{.citex}  
    [the two beaters of you]{.trans}  
    (from [الضاربان]{.ar})

(@) [الضارِبوك]{.ar}
    [[[شرح ابن يعيش على المفصل]{.ar} 2/135](https://shamela.ws/book/13301/585#p1)]{.citex}  
    [the beaters of you]{.trans}  
    (from [الضاربون]{.ar})

(@) [ضاربايَ]{.ar}
    [[[شرح ابن يعيش على المفصل]{.ar} 2/135](https://shamela.ws/book/13301/585#p1)]{.citex}  
    [the two beaters of me]{.trans}  
    (from [الضاربَان]{.ar})

(@) [الضارِبَيَّ]{.ar}
    [[[شرح ابن يعيش على المفصل]{.ar} 2/135](https://shamela.ws/book/13301/585#p1)]{.citex}  
    [the two beaters of me]{.trans}  
    (from [الضاربَيْن]{.ar})

(@) [الضارِبِيَّ]{.ar}
    [[[شرح ابن يعيش على المفصل]{.ar} 2/135](https://shamela.ws/book/13301/585#p1)]{.citex}  
    [the beaters of me]{.trans}  
    (from [الضاربِين]{.ar} and [الضاربون]{.ar})

Occasionally
a [ن]{.ar} is inserted
between the [ism_fail]{.subs} [mudaf]{.subs}
and the pronoun [mudafil]{.subs}.
This would permit words like:
[ضَارِبُنِي]{.ar},
[الضَّارِبُونِي]{.ar},
etc.
For example:

(@) [فَهَلْ أَنْتُمْ صَادِقُونِي فِيهِ]{.ar}
    ^[also narrated as [صَادِقِيَّ]{.ar} in [[صحيح البخاري]{.ar} :3169](https://sunnah.com/bukhari:3169)]
    [<https://hadithunlocked.com/nasai-kubra:11291>]{.citex}  
    [So will you tell me the truth about it?]{.trans}  

It seems that this usage did not make its way to Standard Classical Arabic.
But some grammarians permit this usage
by poetic license,
or as a rare usage.^[See for more details [[شرح كتاب سيبويه للسيرافي]{.ar} 2/44](https://shamela.ws/book/17726/542); [[النحو الوافي]{.ar} 1/285](https://shamela.ws/book/10641/284); [[شرح ابن يعيش على المفصل]{.ar} 2/137](https://shamela.ws/book/13301/587#p1); Wright 2/67AB]

## The [faa3il]{.subs} of a [mushtaqq]{.subs} noun that fulfils the role of the [xabar]{.subs}

In our discussion of the [faa3il]{.subs} of [mushtaqq]{.subs} nouns,
we have consistently stated that the [faa3il]{.subs} of a [mushtaqq]{.subs} noun is not a [3umdah]{.subs} element.
This is because the [mushtaqq]{.subs} noun, which has a [faa3il]{.subs}, is typically already part of an existing sentence.
See example (@3amal_mush_zaydun_daaribun_aboohu_3amran) [زَيْدٌ ضَارِبٌ أَبُوهُ عَمْرًا]{.ar} above.

However, there is one special kind of sentence where 
that the [faa3il]{.subs} of a [mushtaqq]{.subs} noun _is_ a [3umdah]{.subs} element.

Before presenting this special 
_[faa3il]{.subs}-that-fulfils-the-role-of-the-[xabar]{.subs}_
sentence,
we will first give some background.
Consider the sentence:

(@3amal_mush_zaydun_qaaimun2) [زَيْدٌ قَائِمٌ]{.ar}  
    [Zayd is standing.]{.trans}

In example (@3amal_mush_zaydun_qaaimun2) above,
[زَيْدٌ]{.ar}
is the [mubtada]{.subs}
and
[قَائِمٌ]{.ar}
is its [xabar]{.subs}.

We can rearrange the word order to front the [xabar]{.subs} thus:

(@3amal_mush_qaaimun_zaydun) [قَائِمٌ زَيْدٌ]{.ar}  
    [Standing, Zayd is.]{.trans}

This fronted [xabar]{.subs} will be common in negative and question sentences.
For example:

(@3amal_mush_aqaaimun_zaydun) [أَقَائِمٌ زَيْدٌ]{.ar}
    [Wright 2/257B]{.citex}  
    [Is Zayd standing?]{.trans}

(@3amal_mush_maa_qaaimun_zaydun) [مَا قَائِمَةٌ هِنْدٌ]{.ar}
    [Wright 2/257B]{.citex}  
    [Hind is not going]{.trans}

Now we come to the special
[faa3il]{.subs}-that-fulfils-the-role-of-the-[xabar]{.subs}
sentence:

In negative and question sentences like
examples (@3amal_mush_aqaaimun_zaydun) and (@3amal_mush_aqaaimun_zaydun) above,
the [mushtaqq]{.subs} noun can be analyzed as a [mubtada]{.subs},
and its following [faa3il]{.subs} will fulfil the role of the [xabar]{.subs}.

So,
in examples (@3amal_mush_aqaaimun_zaydun) and (@3amal_mush_aqaaimun_zaydun) above,
[قَائِمٌ]{.ar}
can be considered a [mubtada]{.subs}
[زَيْدٌ]{.ar}
and can be its [faa3il]{.subs} that fulfils the role of the [xabar]{.subs}.
Now, you might be thinking:
what is the reason for this strange
[faa3il]{.subs}-that-fulfils-the-role-of-the-[xabar]{.subs}
analysis?

Why can't we just consider
[قَائِمٌ]{.ar}
a fronted [xabar]{.subs} and 
[زَيْدٌ]{.ar}
the backed [mubtada]{.subs}?

The answer is that we can indeed
consider
[قَائِمٌ]{.ar}
a fronted [xabar]{.subs} and 
[زَيْدٌ]{.ar}
the backed [mubtada]{.subs} as one option.
But, as another option,
the
[faa3il]{.subs}-that-fulfils-the-role-of-the-[xabar]{.subs}
analysis allows us to keep the [mushtaqq]{.subs} noun in the singular for dual and plural subjects.
So we can say:

(@3amal_mush_aqaaimun_alzaydaani) [أَقَائِمٌ الزَّيْدَانِ]{.ar}  
    [Are the two Zayds standing?]{.trans}

(@3amal_mush_maa_qaaimun_alhindaatu) [مَا ذَاهِبَةٌ الْهِنْدَاتُ]{.ar}  
    [The Hinds are not going]{.trans}

Sentences (@3amal_mush_aqaaimun_alzaydaani) and (@3amal_mush_maa_qaaimun_alhindaatu) are legitimate, but are only permitted for negative and question sentences.^[Some grammarians did not require this condition based on the sentence [خَبِيرٌ بَنُو لِهْبٍ]{.ar}. For details on the dispute, see [[أوضح المسالك لابن هشام]{.ar}\ 1/191 footnote 3](https://shamela.ws/book/11825/193#p1).]
If it is not a negative or question sentence, then
the
[faa3il]{.subs}-that-fulfils-the-role-of-the-[xabar]{.subs}
construction is not permitted.
So the following are not correct as complete sentences:

(@3amal_mush_qaaimun_alzaydaani) [x]{.subs} [قَائِمٌ الزَّيْدَانِ]{.ar}  
    [The two Zayds are standing.]{.trans}

(@3amal_mush_qaaimatun_alhindaatu) [x]{.subs} [ذَاهِبَةٌ  الْهِنْدَاتُ]{.ar}  
    [The Hinds are going]{.trans}

This is because the [mushtaqq]{.subs} noun
[قَائِم]{.ar}
cannot govern the [zaahir]{.subs} [faa3il]{.subs}s
[الزَّيْدَانِ]{.ar}
and
[الْهِنْدَاتُ]{.ar}
without the [i3timaad]{.subs} that is provided by being in a negative or question sentence.

So when it is not a negative or question sentence, then only the fronted [xabar]{.subs} construction is permitted and the [xabar]{.subs} will typically match the backed [mubtada]{.subs} in number and gender. For example:

(@3amal_mush_qaaimaani_alzaydaani) [قَائِمَانِ الزَّيْدَانِ]{.ar}  
    [Standing, the two Zayds are.]{.trans}

(@3amal_mush_qaaimun_alhindaatu) [ذَاهِبَاتٌ  الْهِنْدَاتُ]{.ar}  
    [Going, the Hinds are.]{.trans}

The fronted [xabar]{.subs} construction is also permitted, as an option, even for negative and question sentences.
For example:

(@3amal_mush_aqaaimaani_alzaydaani) [أَقَائِمَانِ الزَّيْدَانِ]{.ar}  
    [Are the two Zayds standing?]{.trans}

(@3amal_mush_maa_qaaimun_alhindaatu) [مَا ذَاهِبَاتٌ الْهِنْدَاتُ]{.ar}  
    [The Hinds are not going]{.trans}

When the [mushtaqq]{.subs} noun and the [faa3il]{.subs} are both singular, and it is a negative or question sentence,
then a double analysis is possible^[Wright 2/258A]:

 i. the fronted [xabar]{.subs} analysis
ii. the [faa3il]{.subs}-that-fulfils-the-role-of-the-[xabar]{.subs} analysis

Such is the case in examples (@3amal_mush_aqaaimun_zaydun) [أَقَائِمٌ زَيْدٌ]{.ar}
and (@3amal_mush_maa_qaaimun_zaydun) [مَا قَائِمَةٌ هِنْدٌ]{.ar} above.


Here are some more examples of
[faa3il]{.subs}-that-fulfils-the-role-of-the-[xabar]{.subs}
sentences:

(@) [هَلْ مَضْرُوبٌ بَنُوكَ]{.ar}
    [Wright 2/257C]{.citex}  
    [Are your sons beaten?]{.trans}  
    ([بَنُو]{.ar} is a [naib]{.subs} [faa3il]{.subs}.)

(@) [أَرَاغِبٌ أَنتَ عَنۡ ءَالِهَتِی یَـٰۤإِبۡرَ ٰ⁠هِیمُۖ]{.quran}
    [[[سورة مريم]{.ar} 19:46](https://quran.com/19/46) cited by Wright 2/257D]{.citex}  
    [Have you no desire for my gods, O Abraham?]{.trans}  
    (A double analysis is reportedly possible, but the [faa3il]{.subs}-that-fulfils-the-role-of-the-[xabar]{.subs} analysis is preferred.^[See [[البحر المحيط لأبي حيان]{.ar}](https://tafsir.app/albahr-almuheet/19/46) for [سورة مريم]{.ar} 19:46])

(@) [خَلِيلَيَّ مَا وَافٍ بِعَهْدِي أَنْتُمَا]{.ar}
    [Wright 2/257D]{.citex}  
    [My two friends, you are not keeping my promise.]{.trans}

(@) [أَمُنْجِزٌ أَنْتُمْ وَعْدًا وَثِقْتُ بِهِ]{.ar}
    [Wright 2/257D]{.citex}  
    [Are you fulfiling a promise that I put my trust on?]{.trans}

## The [masdar]{.subs} as a verb-like governor

<https://shamela.ws/book/36130/1479#p1>

[مسألة الفرق بين اسم الفاعل والمصدر في العمل - كتاب ما لم ينشر من الأمالي الشجرية - ابن الشجري]{.ar}

[[الدرر السنية]{.ar}](https://dorar.net/arabia/629/%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%85%D8%B7%D9%84%D8%A8-%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%A3%D9%88%D9%84-%D8%A3%D8%AD%D9%88%D8%A7%D9%84-%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%85%D8%B5%D8%AF%D8%B1-%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%B9%D8%A7%D9%85%D9%84-%D8%B9%D9%85%D9%84-%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%81%D8%B9%D9%84#:~:text=%D9%88%D9%87%D8%B0%D8%A7%20%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%AA%D8%B1%D8%AA%D9%8A%D8%A8%D9%8F%20%D9%85%D9%86%20%D8%AD%D9%8A%D8%AB%D9%8F%20%D9%83%D9%8E%D8%AB%D8%B1%D8%A9%D9%8F,%D8%A3%D8%BA%D8%B6%D8%A8%D9%86%D9%8A%20%D8%A3%D9%86%20%D9%8A%D9%8E%D8%B6%D8%B1%D9%90%D8%A8%D9%8E%20%D8%B2%D9%8E%D9%8A%D8%AF%D9%8C%20%D8%B9%D9%8E%D9%85%D9%92%D8%B1%D9%8B%D8%A7.)
